title: advertising that “cancer is curable,” peddled his arsenic compounds through the mails. He eventually served four years in Leavenworth for mail fraud. Harry Hoxsey attracted thousands of dying patients to his Dallas clinic for a treatment that combined potassium iodide, red clover, poke root, prickly ash bark, and other herbal aids. It took the FDA more than two decades of litigation before it shut him down in 1960. The two were only the most famous of dozens of charlatans who “worked the cancer angle
